questionsone.prompt: Is a red-red-blue-gold resistor nominal value greater than 45M-ohms?
questionsone.hint: Red-Red-Blue means 22 followed by 6 zeros (22,000,000 ohms = 22M ohms)

questionsone.prompt: This the schematic symbol of a bulb?
questionsone.hint: A bulb symbol has a circle with an X or filament inside

questionsone.prompt: Conventional Current flows from Negative(-) to Positive(+)?
questionsone.hint: Conventional current flows from positive to negative terminal

questionsone.prompt: Ohm's Law is represented by the equation V=(I)(R)?
Do Capacitors store energy in an electric field between plates?
questionsone.hint: Capacitors store energy in an electric field between plates

questionstwo.prompt: Does a diode allow current to flow in both directions?
questionstwo.hint: Diodes are one-way gates for current flow

questionstwo.prompt: Is the unit of resistance called the Ohm?
questionstwo.hint: Resistance is measured in Ohms (Ω), named after Georg Ohm

questionstwo.prompt: In a series circuit, current is the same at all points?
questionstwo.hint: In series circuits, the same current flows through all components

questionstwo.prompt: Does an LED emit light when reverse biased?
questionstwo.hint: LEDs only emit light when forward biased (current flows forward)

questionstwo.prompt: Is a transistor a three-terminal device?
questionstwo.hint: Transistors have three terminals: base, collector, and emitter

questionsthree.prompt: Does a short circuit have infinite resistance?
questionsthree.hint: A short circuit has almost zero resistance (direct connection)

questionsthree.prompt: In parallel circuits, voltage is the same across all branches?
questionsthree.hint: Parallel circuits share the same voltage across all branches

questionsthree.prompt: Is AC current the same as DC current?
questionsthree.hint: AC alternates direction, DC flows in one direction only

questionsthree.prompt: Does a fuse protect a circuit by opening when current is too high?
questionsthree.hint: Fuses contain a wire that melts and breaks the circuit when overloaded
Power is measured in Watts (W), calculated as P = V × I
